Violation_Type: Failure to consider compelling reasons exception under s. 108(4) of IRPA
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in failing to consider the 'compelling reasons' exception under s. 108(4) of IRPA after finding changed circumstances
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 108(4)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection based on past persecution in Sri Lanka; Board found changed circumstances but did not address s. 108(4); applicant's testimony on past torture was corroborated and not discredited
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: The Board erred by not considering s. 108(4); case referred back for reconsideration
Defendant_Behavior: Board failed to apply s. 108(4) despite evidence of past persecution
Grounds_for_Claim: Past persecution, including torture in Sri Lanka
Legal_Standard: Under s. 108(4) of IRPA, if protection grounds have ceased, the Board must assess whether compelling reasons arising from past persecution prevent cessation
Assessment_Factor: Existence of changed country conditions, credibility of past persecution, presence of compelling reasons due to past persecution
Procedural_Issue: Board omitted required legal analysis under s. 108(4)
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony on torture was corroborated and not discredited
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, corroboration of torture allegations
Application_Basis: Refugee protection based on past persecution and risk upon return
Evidence_Assessed: Testimony regarding past torture, country condition changes
Relief_Sought: Allowance of refugee claim or remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: s. 108(4) of IRPA requires consideration of compelling reasons due to past persecution even if protection grounds have ceased
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to assess whether compelling reasons existed despite finding of changed circumstances
Outcome: Application granted; matter remitted to Refugee Protection Division
Decisional_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board (Refugee Protection Division)
Harm_Assessment: Risk of re-traumatization or harm due to past persecution if returned
Cause_Description: Sabaratnam claimed refugee protection based on past persecution in Sri Lanka. The Board rejected his claim citing changed circumstances but failed to consider s. 108(4) IRPA
Evidence_Handling: Credible and corroborated evidence of past torture was not adequately addressed in legal analysis
Evidence_Issues: Failure to link credible evidence of past persecution to legal test under s. 108(4)
Evidence_Assessment: Prima facie evidence of past persecution established through credible and corroborated testimony
Decision_Rationale: Board committed an error of law by not applying s. 108(4) after finding changed circumstances
Decision_Making_Body: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board
Evidentiary_Issues: Omission of required analysis under s. 108(4) despite sufficient evidence of past persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: Correctness standard applied to legal interpretation of s. 108(4) IRPA
